Wear this to any classy event you go to... in the 1980's. Created by Todd Blatt and as everyone knows, invented by Mugatu

Make all the parts in all three plates: black.stl, white1.stl and white2.stl.  They assemble from smallest to largest and are put on the plate in order.  Thread a cord through the knot piece, down through all the keys on one side, and then back up through the holes in the keys on the other side, and back through the knot.  They tie the cord around through your collar on your shirt and you're good to go.  When in doubt, reference the allparts.stl file, though that one wont fit on the build platform.  This tie would work if you scaled everything down 80% or just leave it as is.
-Todd

description.text:
I needed a conversion plate to mount a nema 17 stepper motor onto a nema 23 mounting point. This was in relation to a hobby CNC milling machine that I have, where I am fiddling around with ideas for a 4th axis. I couldn't find exactly what I wanted on Thingiverse so figured I would create my own.  
Whilst fiddling around I decided to create several nema 17 mounts, which would allow a stepper motor to be mounted at different heights away from the nema 23 location. I think this might potentially be useful if I ever wanted to implement a raise and lower gate a la the Thames barrier which can be raised/lowered to prevent London from flooding (okay, daft idea but sometimes things like this prove useful).
Created using TinkerCAD.

title: Stronger Extruder Idler for Eckertech Extruder

description.text: The default idler splits between layers after repeated tightening, it also can't be made sufficiently tight on hobbed bolts cut any deeper than their own bolt which is " widely considered the best hobbed bolt on the market", they really said that. Anyway, I made a clone in openscad that prints the other way up so the layer bonding is no longer an issue. It should be printed in PLA, ABS will flex and weaken over time, PLA is more rigid. As you can see in the video it slots in as nicely as the original. Any issues, let me know and I'll see about improving the part. http://youtu.be/HmJ9fMMfU7o
Print in PLA. STLs with and without support provided.

title: Replicator Dual - Nozzle Centring Script (That actually works)

description.text:
The script included with ReplicatorG is either designed for a Single or a Dual Replicator I can not tell, but it doesn't with a Dual!  It also has the potential to crash the nozzles into the HBP.
This new script homes all axis', moves Z down .5mm, moves the carriage/right nozzle to "stored centre" and allows you to adjust it if required.  I've also adjusted the Z speed as suggested on Google Groups by someone (I don't remember who).
I've read many posts on this issue, it's been suggested to position the carriage centre (ie between the dual nozzles), but that doesn't work either.
This script may work with a Replicator Single as well, but I can not verify that.

UPDATE: From my understanding this will not work with Makerbot v6 firmware and above, it might work with Sailfish but I have not installed that yet. UPDATE: I have tried this with Sailfish 7.3 using ReplicatorG 0040r11 on a Replicator 1 and it works perfectly. NOTE: Use the Right Nozzle "A" in all alignment steps, the Left Nozzle or "B" has an offset built into the .xml settings file of 33.1mm. I believe this is the main source of issues as most believe your supposed to centre the carriage not the nozzle! This script is also safer (reduced speeds, won't drag the nozzle across the HBP etc..). And if you run it multiple times you don't have to start over at the home position!!
  • This has been tested with ReplicatorG v37 & v5.5 firmware
    1) Put script in your *\ReplicatorG\replicatorg-00xx\scripts\calibration directory/folder
    2) Connect Replicator via USB (this won't work off the SD as there's prompts built in... The default script requires USB as well)
    3) Start ReplicatorG
    4) Open the new script: File -> Scripts -> calibration -> "The Replicator Nozzle Centring.gcode"
    5) Using a ruler create an X in the dead centre of your HBP
    6) Click "Build"
    7) It will prompt you a few times and give you directions (both on the machine and screen)
    8) The script will first home the axis', move Z down .5mm. Move the carriage and position the RIGHT nozzle over the currently stored centre and then disable the steppers
    9) If the RIGHT nozzle is not directly over the centre please adjust it and press Yes to save your settings.
    • After running the script my replicator now prints in the exact centre of the HBP regardless of which nozzle is used! (Or wherever you tell ReplicatorG to print your object) If your HBP sags more than .5mm when heated. You can adjust the following (by default I move the HBP down .5mm to prevent dragging of the nozzles):
    G1 Z0.5 F100 ( * NOTE: Change this if your platform sags more than .5mm when heated...)
     1mm would be "G1 Z1.0 F100" NOTE: You can run the script as many times as you wish to double check the stored settings. Just click "No" after it positions the nozzle over the centre mark if you don't want to change anything. New script uploaded 2012/08/24 3:45pm EST as I saw a spelling error nothing else has changed :)

comments.text: Glad to hear.. I've used it on Sailfish as well.. Very handy when I upgraded to the Bottleworks glass platform too.
comments.author: Fastrack

comments.text: Works on CTC dual, sailfish 7.7
comments.author: adamcooks

author: Fastrack

description.text:
Getting a 3D printer bed level is critical for producing decent printed objects. I found that the 4 screws of my FF Creator combined with a sheet of paper couldn't get me near to the accurate position I wanted, so I designed this object.  
To use, start by leveling the build plate as near as possible using the mechanical raise/lower screws. Then run this print. If you are using Simplify3D then turn on the skirt option, as that helps. With Simplify3D you can also define to stop printing at a given height, and if you set this to the layer height of your bot then it will print just that one layer (which is all you are really interested in).  
Set your print speed reasonably low. This gives you time to do manual adjustments to your build plate level in real time. Once you've got your build plate level you can experiment with the speed to find what speed is right for your bot and filament to print that first layer.  
As the first layer goes down, manually micro-adjust the mechanical screws to get the height right in the corners and centre. The ideal situation is that the bot leaves the print on the build plate without dragging it, and without a break. It can take a little time to get this right, but by repeating the process I was able to quickly get my build plate to be completely level across the whole surface. I found this to be quite intuitive - and I was quickly able to see issues relating to height which I could quickly smooth out.  
This lily pad design is intended for the FF Creator and similar bots which have a 230x150 build plate. It will work for larger plates.  
Furthermore, in reaching this design I implemented it such that once printed it can be pulled off of the build plate on one easy go. All of the components of the design are connected together, so once you've got your build plate level you can run this design, and then clean the plate without having to fiddle around removing islands of printing.
Created using TinkerCAD.

author: Sculptor

title: Parametric lamp shade (CNC / laser cutting) in OpenJsCad

description.text: Interactive parametric lamp shade! Built with OpenJsCad. OpenJsCad now supports 2D modeling and DXF output as well! In this design the lamp shade is first modeled in 3D, then 2D panels are extracted for CNC cutting. Interactive model here: http://joostn.github.com/OpenJsCad/lampshadedemo.html More about OpenJsCad: http://joostn.github.com/OpenJsCad

To create your own custom lamp shade go to: http://joostn.github.com/OpenJsCad/
(scroll down to Examples and choose Parametric Lampshade) Enter desired parameters and click Update. Drag the model around in the browser (Alt-drag zooms in/out). When you like the result, choose: Show: Top plate (DXF Output) Quality: High and click Update Click Generate DXF to obtain the 2D DXF file for cutting. Repeat for the side plate.

author: joostn

remixed_from.author: ScribbleJ
remixed_from.title: Parametric Herringbone Gear Set for Stepper Extruders

description.text:
I've recreated the extruder body from the Prusa i3 rework, then translated the motor mount about 5mm toward the -x direction in order to make it easier to then switch the gears to the herringbone design, based on changes to the script by ScribbleJ (also the hex insert is now sized more appropriately for an M8 hobbed bolt than the original).  The tooth ratio on the gears is 37/13 (original was 43/10, so adjust esteps accordingly).  
Also, I increased the size of the holes slightly on the idler and added a thumb grip to make it easier to use.  The fan duct and X carriage are unchanged but included here for completeness.  
This is also the extruder now maintained as part of the reprap Wilson design.  
UPDATE 5-21-14: I have made some small tweaks to the body and idler to make them easier to print, decreased the fulcrum width a smidge on the body, increased the filament guide hole by .15mm, and made the slots in the idler a little narrower.

comments.text: Very good, congratulations.
comments.author: lyllen

comments.text:
Suggestion for 1.75mm version.
Hobbed bolts are not optimum for this size filament, especially with PLA and all metal hot ends (increased back pressure). This drive gear:
http://3d-industries.myshopify.com/collections/prusa-spares/products/filament-drive-gear-hobb-post-sale
has excellent grip. How about a mod for this extruder to use a 5mm bolt instead of the hobbed bolt onto which this drive gear is attached? Would require modding the large gear (maybe change gear ratio and bolt head hex size), use smaller bearings, and change filament guide holes. While at it add post drive gear filament support for nijaflex.
comments.author: scharkalvin

comments.text: Has anybody tried using a e3d hotend with this design?
comments.author: richard_j_m

comments.text: What size filament is the extruder body designed for?
comments.author: AbbyJones

comments.text: The feed hole is about 3.5mm in diameter.  I've used it for both 1.75mm and 3mm filament.  I've heard people say they prefer it smaller when using the smaller filament, but to be honest I don't know how much it matters as long as you don't have a lot of heat creep on your hot end.  I'd like to know more about that, though.
comments.author: AbbyJones

comments.text:
Thanks for the reply. I prefer to have a smaller diameter for 1.75 filament. It helps to feed the filament into the top of the hot end and may also prevent filament buckling when using a more flexible filament like Ninja Flex and such.
If it's not too much trouble, please add a smaller diameter version or post the source files to we can modify them.
comments.author: mrice

comments.text: You could drill it out to 4mm and then use a 4mm OD, 2mm ID piece of Teflon tubing glued in place as a guide.

remixed_from.author: SKG
remixed_from.title: Raspberry Pi Case with Hex Bolts

title: Raspberry Pi case with holes for M3 screws

description.text: Most Raspberry Pi cases do not use screws to stick the top and bottom together. These screwless cases have the disadvantages that top and bottom do not stick well together. In addition, top and bottom must fit perfectly. The latter is often hard to achieve with consumer 3d printers. Therefore, I searched for a case that keeps top and bottom together using screws. The user SKL designed a Raspberry Pi Case with Hex Bolts (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:77499). I, however, did not like the screw size. So, I decided to create a new design with M3 screws, instead. As SKL did not provide the source SCAD-files, but only the stl files, I used the design of lincomatic (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:24945) as a starting point. I used a RepRap Mendel to print the case. M3 screws of 25mm length are required to screw top and bottom together.

The file raspberrypi_logo.dxf of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16104 is required, to compile the case with the raspberry logo from the SCAD-files. Place the file in the same folder as the SCAD-file.

comments.text: Thanks!

The very "informative" and "helpful" robot you encounter in the video game Borderlands. He moves with one wheel and is shaped like a Chinese take out box. I originally made him because I thought it was such a funny design for a robot and I thought it would be easy to make because of its simple geometry.
I'm still working out the different parts that will move and when I do I will split him into his respective parts so he can be easily assembled.

author: WilliamGilliam

description.text:
C87 - servo saver part 3  
This steering part is for the ACME Raptor Truggy.

For the servo saver which easily broke down are two models.
  • Original, but is two weak when printed
  • Modified stronger version which works great.
    • Printsettings:
    The mod version can be printed without raft and supports if the flat side is under and gives the best result.
    100% fill with 2 shells and layerheigtht not to low, choose 0.2 or higher. After printing the holes must be drilled with:
  • big hole with 4.0mm
  • mid hole with 3.5mm
  • small new hole 2.5mm
    Assembling the axle with some grease for low resistance.

Filament Spool Holder Prusa i3, coil diameter 210 mm.
To version Adjustable Filament Spool Holder Prusa I3 http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:295055

For installation you need:
  • All plastic parts published
  • 8 bolts allen M4 x 20 mm
  • 8 nuts M4
  • 4 bolts allen M4 x 25 mm
  • 4 nuts M4
  • 1x170 mm Threaded rod M8
  • 2x230 mm Threaded rod M8
  • 10 nuts M8 + 10 washer M8
  • 2 bearings 608

I wanted to get back into the swing of designing mechanical things from solely laser cut parts and, as I just got myself a nice 60Watt laser, I thought it would be nice to cut myself a little mechanical cat. It stands about 3" high, is made out of super friendly .125" pressboard, and features the distinctive face of the Internet Defense League's cat signal { http://internetdefenseleague.org/ }.

This cat is made of Laserbits .125" pressboard { http://www.laserbits.com/index.php?main_page=product_info&cPath=82_352&products_id=980 } and is fastened together using .5" and 1" 6/32 screws, nuts, and washers. Just cut the plans on your favorite laser, assemble, and enjoy hours of mechanical cuteness. Play with adding washers in between the different cut pieces to get everything to move without snagging. I ended up stacking two washers together in a few places to make sure I could pose the cat without any screws knocking against each other.
Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:58001 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=58001

An old classic in a new look: The Stanford Bunny - Voronoi Style.
Print your favourite bunny for family and friends and put it into their Easter basket. I included six (!) different models, each with a different "resolution". I took the original file direct from Stanford and modified it a bit to fit my needs.
Credits go to the Stanford Computer Graphics Laboratory.
https://graphics.stanford.edu/data/3Dscanrep/ Animation on Youtube:
http://youtu.be/4AqhtWmodJo

description.text:
Protective frame around the propellers of the Q-Bot micro quadcopter from HobbyKing. Enables you to (more) safely fly the copter indoors. Design made in TinkerCad, "source" available here:
https://tinkercad.com/things/biNEElakWrs-q-bot-protection

To save weight, remove the canopy and fit the frame with each notch over the four booms. BOM:
  • Printed frame part
  • 4 pieces of string or wire
    • Wrap the string or wire through the hole in each notch to secure it in place.

title: Betrayal at the House on the Hill Marker

description.text: Played Betrayal on the House on the Hill last night for Table Top Day, and the little card markers for your stats kept sliding off. So I printed some new ones today. Simple friction fit, I printed a couple till they fit snugly with my printer. The tolerances are so tight your printers calibration might come into play. This thing was made with Tinkercad. author: aleiovanevcp

title: Hook plate for IKEA Bästis (Hook dog)

description.text:
I modeled this hook plate for the IKEA Bästis hook that looks like a dog.
The original plate cracked and was not able to keep the Dog hook mounted to the wall. So I decided to print a replacement part. I printed it in PLA with a support structure generated by slicer.
After cleaning the part with a utility knife it snapped in place with the dog part. Now the hook is mounted on the wall again.

comments.text: Great!!! Thanks! - I was just going to build it myself, since mine was broken ... and it's there already. The 3D community is the best!
comments.author: yvichrome
